content.description: The crux is down low which can be climbed on the thin seam or on the face to the left. A spotter is recommended for the start, as there is little good protection down low. Look for a thread after the crux.
content.protection: TR this with a #2, #3, and #4. Make sure the masterpoint is out of the crack. On lead, there’s a solid thread, and other placements are possible.
content.location: It ascends the thin seam that widens up top, about 10-15 feet to the left of the dihedral.

content.description: This is a fun layback, and you can also jam your feet. Try handjamming, but you’ll likely find it’s too painful due to the pebbly nature of the rock. The crux is up top, especially if you decide to top out.
content.protection:
A bouldering pad.

Also, this is fun to place gear on if you want, it protects well the whole way up but gets progressively wider. The bottom is around a #0.75 or #1. At the top, you get either a tipped out #4 that you need to look around for a good enough placement or a #5 (which would be preferred). A TR anchor can be made using crack to the left up top if you extend it over to this route, placing a large cam to redirect and hold masterpoint in place is a good idea to prevent masterpoint from sliding out of crack.
content.location: It is located at the dihedral near large boulder. This ascends the large, obvious crack with a nice, flat base.

pathTokens: Denver Metropolitan Area Bouldering and Buildering
